titleStmt.title: Lag Synchronization of Memristor-Based Coupled Neural Networks via ω-Measure

analytic.title: Lag Synchronization of Memristor-Based Coupled Neural Networks via ω-Measure

biblStruct.note: received April 30, 2014; revised July 2, 2015; accepted September 18, 2015.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This paper deals with the lag synchronization problem of memristor-based coupled neural networks with or without parameter mismatch using two different algorithms. Firstly, we consider the memristor-based neural networks with parameter mismatch, lag complete synchronization cannot be achieved due to parameter mismatch, the concept of lag quasisynchronization is introduced. Based on the ω-measure method and generalized Halanay inequality, the error level is estimated, a new lag quasi-synchronization scheme is proposed to ensure that coupled memristor-based neural networks are in a state of lag synchronization with an error level. Secondly, by constructing Lyapunov functional and applying common Halanary inequality, several lag complete synchronization criteria for the memristorbased neural networks with parameter match are given, which are easy to verify. Finally, two examples are given to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed lag quasi-synchronization or lag complete synchronization criteria, which well support theoretical results.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: B EFORE the memristor was found, which was first proposed by Chua [1] in 1971, it is well known that there are three basic circuit elements: 1) resistance; 2) capacitance; and 3) inductance. These elements are used to describe the relations between fundamental electrical quantities: 1) voltage; 2) current; 3) charge; and 4) flux. Resistance relates voltage and current (R = (dv/di)), capacitance relates charge and voltage (C = (dq/dv)), and inductance relates flux and current (L = (dϕ/di)), respectively. However, Chua [1] realized that there was a missing link between flux ϕ and charge q, as shown in Fig. 1 [2], which he called memristance; it could describe the nonlinear relation between flux and charge (M(q) = (dϕ/dq)). Memristor did not cause much scholars' attentions until Hewlett-Packard (HP) Labs [3] built it successfully in 2008, an actual classical physical memristor model (Fig. 2); it consists of a two-layer thin film of TiO 2 , sandwiched between platinum contacts, one TiO 2-x layer is called doped area with oxygen vacancies and acts like a semiconductor, whereas another TiO 2 layer is called undoped area, which acts as a resistor. It acts as a series resistor, and its total memristance is a sum of the resistances of the doped and undoped regions, that is, R m = R ON w/D + R OFF (1 -w/D). Another character of the memristor is that, when being driven by a bipolar periodic signal, it must exhibit pinched hysteresis loop in the voltage-current plane (Fig. 3). Memristor [4] has been applied to several fields, since it has distinct memory property and nanoscale, such that it can be used to Hopfiled neural networks to mimic the memory and forgetting effect in the human memory.

Recently, dynamical behaviors of memristor-based neural networks have attracted researchers' attentions, and synchronization or antisynchronization in coupled networks is one of the most important collective dynamical behaviors [5]- [7]. Some works dealing with the synchronization or antisynchronization phenomena of the memristor-based neural networks have also appeared [8]- [12]. In [8], based on the driveresponse concept, differential inclusions theory, and Lyapunov functional method, two different types of antisynchronization algorithms were derived to achieve the exponential antisynchronization of the coupled systems. Yang et al. [12] considered memristor-based Cohen-Grossberg neural networks with unbounded distributed delays; through a nonlinear transformation, an alternative system was obtained from the considered memristor-based Cohen-Grossberg neural networks; the corresponding synchronization criteria were easy to verify and improved the conditions derived in most of the existing papers. However, there are several different types of synchronization phenomena, such as complete synchronization [13], phase synchronization [14], lag synchronization [15], generalized synchronization [16], and so on. Among them, lag synchronization [17], [18] can be a reasonable scheme from the viewpoint of practical applications and the characteristics of channel due to the inevitable signal transmittal delay between the master system and the slave system, and it has been applied in different areas, including secure communication, parallel image processing, and pattern storage. In addition, parameter mismatch [19], [20] is inevitable in practical implementations in the case of the noises or other artificial factors, and it plays an important role in the quality of synchronization. Above all, this motivates us to study the lag synchronization of memristor-based neural networks with or without parameter mismatch. To the best of our knowledge, there has been no literature concerning the problems of synchronization for the memristor-based neural networks with or without parameter mismatch.

Inspired by the above-mentioned discussions, in this paper, different from the methods dealing with the memristorbased neural networks, by introducing ω-measure method and generalized Halanay inequality, several simple and easily verified criteria are derived to ensure the lag synchronization of memristor-based neural networks [21] with or without parameter mismatch. It is shown that lag complete synchronization cannot reach under the case of parameter mismatch, but the error level is estimated accurately. It should be noted that activation functions are required to satisfy f i (±T i ) = 0 or other strong assumption; here, we remove the strong condition. Hence, the proposed results in this paper improve and extend the previous results.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In Section II, the model formulation and some preliminaries are presented. In Section III, lag quasi-synchronization control criteria for memristive neural networks under parameter mismatch are derived. Some synchronization criteria for memristive neural networks with parameter match are obtained in Section IV. Two numerical simulations are presented to demonstrate the validity of the proposed results. The conclusions are drawn in Section V.

Notation: Throughout this paper, R denotes the set of real numbers, R n denotes the n-dimensional Euclidean space, [•, •] represents the interval, and co(Q) denotes the closure of the convex hull of Q. I denotes the identity matrix with compatible dimension. For any matrix A, A T denotes the transpose of A, and λ max (A) and λ min (A) denote the maximum and minimum eigenvalue of A, respectively. Given the vectors x = (x 1 , . . . , x n ) T ∈ R n , x denotes the Euclidian vector norm, and x ω is denoted as the ω-norm. For τ > 0, C([-τ, 0]; R n ) denotes the family of continuous function ϕ from [-τ, 0] to R n . Matrices, if their dimensions not explicitly stated, are assumed to have compatible dimensions for algebraic operations.

div.head: II. NETWORKS MODEL AND PRELIMINARIES
div.p: We consider the simplified memristor-based neural networks with time-varying delay [10]
div.formula: ẋi (t) = -d i (x i (t))x i (t) + n j =1 a i j (x i (t)) f j (x j (t)) + n j =1 b i j (x i (t))g j (x j (t -τ (t))) + I i t ≥ 0, i = 1, 2, . . . , n (1)
div.p: where f j (•) and g j (•) are activation functions, τ (t) is timevarying transmission delay [it satisfies 0 < τ(t) ≤ τ ], I i is the external input, and the connection weight coefficients satisfy
div.formula: d i (x i (t)) = di , |x i (t)| ≤ T i di , |x i (t)| > T i a i j (x i (t)) = áij , |x i (t)| ≤ T i àij , |x i (t)| > T i b i j (x i (t)) = bij , |x i (t)| ≤ T i bij , |x i (t)| > T i . (2
div.p: The switching jumps T i > 0, di > 0, di > 0, áij , àij , bij , and bij , i, j = 1, 2, . . . , n, are constants. The initial values associated with system (1) are
Throughout this paper, we need Assumptions (H 1 ) and (H 1 ).

div.head: Assumption (H 1 ):
div.p: There exist positive constants l ω 1 , l ω 2 , such that
div.formula: f (s 1 ) -f (s 2 ) ω ≤ l ω 1 s 1 -s 2 ω g(s 1 ) -g(s 2 ) ω ≤ l ω 2 s 1 -s 2 ω ∀s 1 , s 2 ∈ R n . Assumption (H 2 ): The time delay τ (t) satisfies 0 ≤ τ (t) ≤ τ .
div.p: From condition (2), it is easy to see that memristor-based recurrent networks are discontinuous switched system. In this case, the solution of (1) is considered in Filippov's sense. In the following, we introduce some definitions about the set-valued map and Filippov solution.
Definition 1 [22]:
div.formula: Let E ⊆ R n , x → F(x)
div.p: is called a set-valued map from E → R n , and if for each point x of a set E ⊆ R n , there corresponds a nonempty set F(x) ⊆ R n .

Definition 2 [22]: A set-valued map F with nonempty values is said to be upper semicontinuous at x 0 ∈ E ⊆ R n , and if for any open set N containing F(x 0 ), there exists a neighborhood M of x 0 such that F(M) ⊆ N. F(x) is said to have a closed (convex, compact) image if for each x ∈ E, F(x) is closed (convex, compact).
Definition 3 [23]: For differential system, dx/dt = f (t, x), where f (t, x) is discontinuous in x. The set-valued map of f (t, x) is defined as
div.formula: F(t, x) = δ>0 μ(N)=0 co[ f (B(x, δ)\N)]
div.p: where B(x, δ) = {y : yx ≤ δ} is the ball of center x and radius δ, intersection is taken over all sets N of measure zero and over all δ > 0, and μ(N) is Lebesgue measure of set N.

A Filippov solution of system (1) with initial condition x(0) = x 0 is absolutely continuous on any subinterval t ∈ [t 1 , t 2 ] of [0, T ], which satisfies x(0) = x 0 , and the differential inclusion
div.formula: dx dt ∈ F(t, x). for a.a. t ∈ [0, T ].
div.p: By applying the above theories of inclusion, the memristorbased networks (1) can be written as follows:
div.formula: ẋi (t) ∈ -co(d i (x i (t)))x i (t) + n j =1 co(a i j , a i j ) f j (x j (t)) + n j =1 co(b i j , b i j ) × g j (x j (t -τ (t))) + I i t ≥ 0, i = 1, 2, . . . , n(3)
div.p: where
div.formula: d i = min{ di , di }, d i = max{ di , di }, a i j = min{ áij , àij }, a i j = max{ áij , àij }, b i j = min{ bij , bij }, b i j = max{ bij , bij },and

co(d i , d i ) = ⎧ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎩ di , |x i (t)| < T i [d i , d i ], |x i (t)| = T i di , |x i (t)| > T i co(a i j , a i j ) = ⎧ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎩ áij , |x i (t)| < T i [a i j , a i j ], |x i (t)| = T i àij , |x i (t)| > T i co(b i j , b i j ) = ⎧ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎩ bij , |x i (t)| < T i [b i j , b i j ], |x i (t)| = T i bij , |x i (t)| > T i .
div.p: Correspondingly, the slave system is designed by
div.formula: ẏi (t) = -d * i (y i (t))y i (t) + n j =1 a * i j (y i (t)) f j (y j (t)) + n j =1 b * i j (y i (t))g j (y j (t -τ (t))) + I i + u i (t) t ≥ 0, i = 1, 2, . . . , n(4)
div.p: where
div.formula: d * i (y i (t)) = d * i , |y i (t)| ≤ T i d * i , |y i (t)| > T i a * i j (x i (t)) = á * i j , |y i (t)| ≤ T i à * i j , |y i (t)| > T i b * i j (x i (t)) = b * i j , |y i (t)| ≤ T i b * i j , |y i (t)| > T i .
div.p: The switching jumps
div.formula: T i > 0, d * i > 0, d * i > 0, á * i j , à * i j , b * i j
div.p: , and b * i j , i, j = 1, 2, . . . , n, are constants. The initial values associated with system (4) are
Analogously, system (4) can be rewritten as
div.formula: ẏi (t) ∈ -co d * i , d * i y i (t) + n j =1 co a * i j , a * i j f j (y j (t)) + n j =1 co b * i j , b * i j × g j (y j (t -τ (t))) + I i + u i (t) t ≥ 0, i = 1, 2, . . . , n(6)
div.p: where
div.formula: d * i = min{ d * i , d * i }, d * i = max{ d * i , d * i }, a * i j = min{ á * i j , à * i j }, a * i j = max{ á * i j , à * i j }, b * i j = min{ b * i j , b * i j }, b * i j = max{ b * i j , b * i j }, and co d * i , d * i = ⎧ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎩ d * i , |y i (t)| < T i d * i , d * i , |y i (t)| = T i d * i , |y i (t)| > T i co a * i j , a * i j = ⎧ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎩ á * i j , |y i (t)| < T i a * i j , a * i j , |y i (t)| = T i à * i j , |y i (t)| > T i co b * i j , b * i j = ⎧ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎩ b * i j , |y i (t)| < T i b * i j , b * i j , |y i (t)| = T i b * i j , |y i (t)| > T i . u i (t)
div.p: is the controller to be designed; due to the finite speed of transmission and spreading, in practical, the output signal transfer from master system (1) to salve system (4) exists unavoidable time delay; hence, we adopt the more practical controller
div.formula: u i (t) = k i (x i (t -σ ) -y i (t)) (7)
div.p: where k i is the control gain and σ is the transmittal delay.
To obtain the main results of this paper, the following definitions and lemmas are introduced.
Definition 4: Slave system (4) is said to be lag quasisynchronized to master system (1) with an error level ω > 0, if there exists a compact set M, such that for any
div.formula: φ i (t), ϕ i (t) ∈ C([-τ, 0]; R n ), and the error e(t) = y(t) -x(t -σ ) converges to M = {e ∈ R n | e(t) ω ≤ ω } as t goes to infinity.
div.p: Definition 5 [24]: The matrix ω-measure of a real square matrix W = (w i j ) n×n is denoted as follows:
div.formula: μ ω (W ) = lim ε-→0 + I + εW ω -1 ε where W ω = max j n i=1 (ω i /ω j )|w i j |
div.p: is the induced ω-norm of matrix W ; here, w i > 0 (i = 1, 2, . . . , n) are any constant numbers, and the corresponding ω-measure is
div.formula: μ ω (W ) = max j ⎧ ⎨ ⎩ w j j + n i=1,i = j ω i ω j |w i j | ⎫ ⎬ ⎭ .
div.p: Similarly, when matrix W is reduced as a vector, then the ω-norm of vector W is denoted as n i=1 ω i |w i |. Remark 1: It should be noted that several results have been given using the matrix measure with μ 1 (W )(μ 1 (W ) = max j {w j j + n i=1,i = j |w i j |}). However, there are few results in ω-measure, and μ 1 (W ) can be seen as a special case of our results, since μ ω (W ) is degenerated as μ 1 (W ) when
div.formula: ω i = const (i = 1, 2, . . . , n).
div.p: Lemma 1: The matrix measure μ ω (•) has the following basic properties: (Halanay Inequality [25]): Let u(t) : [t 0 -τ, ∞) → [0, ∞) be a continuous function, and for all t ≥ t 0 , we have
div.formula: 1) -A ω ≤ μ ω (A) ≤ A ω , ∀A ∈ R n×n ; 2) μ ω (α A) = αμ ω (A), ∀α > 0, A ∈ R n×n ; 3) μ ω (A + B) ≤ μ ω (A) + μ ω (B), ∀A, B ∈ R n×n . Lemma 2
D + u(t) ≤ -au(t) + b sup t -τ ≤θ≤t u(θ ). If a > b > 0, then u(t) ≤ sup t 0 -τ ≤θ≤t 0 u(θ )e -r(t -t 0 ) , t ≥ t 0
div.p: where r > 0 is the unique positive solution of the equation ra + be rτ = 0.
Lemma 3 (Generalized Halanay Inequality [26]): If the nonnegative function u(t) satisfies
div.formula: D + u(t) ≤ γ (t)+α(t)u(t)+β(t) sup t -τ ≤s≤t u(s), t ∈ [t 0 , +∞)
div.p: where the continuous function γ (t) ≥ 0, α(t) ≤ 0, and β(t) ≥ 0, if there exists constant δ, such that the following inequality holds:
div.formula: α(t) + β(t) ≤ -δ < 0, t ∈ [t 0 , +∞) then we have u(t) ≤ γ * δ + sup -∞≤s≤t 0 u(s)e -μ * (t -t 0 )
div.p: where γ * = sup t 0 ≤t ≤∞ γ (t) and μ * = inf t ≥t 0 {μ(t) : μ(t) + α(t) + β(t)e μ(t )τ (t ) = 0}. Lemma 4: Given any real vectors x, y ∈ R n , the following inequality holds: 2x T y ≤ x T x + y T y.

div.head: III. MAIN RESULTS
div.p: In this section, define the lag synchronization error signal as e i (t) = y i (t)-x i (t -σ ), (i = 1, 2, . . . , n). Based on the matrix measure theory and generalized Halanay inequality, we will derive some sufficient conditions for lag quasi-synchronization of memristive neural networks with parameter mismatch. For convenience, define the below notation
div.formula: D ω = max{ D -D * ω , D -D * ω , D -D * ω D -D * ω } A ω = max{ À * -À ω , Á * -Á ω , Á * -À ω À * -Á ω } B ω = max{ B * -B ω , B * -B ω , B * -B ω B * -B ω } where D = diag( d1 , d2 , . . . , dn ), D = diag( d1 , d2 , . . . , dn ), D * = diag( d * 1 , d * 2 , . . . , d * n ), D * = diag( d * 1 , d * 2 , . . . , d * n ), Á = (a i j ) n×n , Á * = (a * i j ) n×n , B = (b i j ) n×n , and B * = (b * i j ) n×n . A. Lag Quasi-Synchronization Criteria Theorem 1: Under Assumptions (H 1 ) and (H 2 ), suppose that = {x ∈ R n | x ω ≤ h 1 ω } and sup t ≥0 { D ω x(t -σ ) ω + A ω f (x(t -σ )) ω + B ω g(x(t -σ - τ (t))) ω } = γ * ω < ∞; if the following equality: max μ ω (-D * -K ) + l ω 1 À * ω , μ ω (-D * -K ) + l ω 1 Á * ω + max l ω 2 B * ω , l ω 2 B * ω ≤ -δ < 0
div.p: holds, then, the trajectory of the error system converges to the following set:
div.formula: M = e ∈ R n | e(t) ω ≤ γ * ω δ (8
div.p: and master system (1) and slave system (4) achieve lag quasisynchronized with an error level ε + (γ * ω /δ), where ε is a arbitrarily small positive constant.
Proof: Consider the following Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional:
According to the especial character of memristive neural networks, its switching rule depends on neuron's state, and we divide the proofs into four steps. Case 1:
div.formula: If |x i (t -σ )| ≤ T i , |y i (t)|
div.p: ≤ T i at time t, then master system (1) and slave system (4) reduce to the following systems, respectively: (10) and
div.formula: ẋi (t -σ ) = -di x i (t -σ ) + n j =1 áij f j (x j (t -σ )) + n i= j bij f j (x j (t -σ -τ (t))) + I i
ẏi (t) = -d * i y i (t)+ n j =1 á * i j f j (y j (t))+ n j =1
div.p: b * i j f j (y j (t -τ (t)))
div.formula: + I i -k i (y i (t) -x i (t -σ )). (11
div.p: Correspondingly, the error system can be written as
div.formula: ėi (t) = -d * i e i (t) + n j =1 á * i j f j (e j (t))+ n j =1
div.p: b * i j g j (e j (t -τ (t)))
div.formula: + di -d * i x i (t -σ ) + n j =1 á * i j -áij f j (x j (t -σ )) + n j =1 b * i j -bij g j (x j (t -σ -τ (t))) -k i e i (t) (12
div.p: where
div.formula: f j (e j (t)) = f j (y j (t)) -f j (x j (t -σ )) and g j (e j (t -τ (t))) = g j (y j (t -τ (t))) -g j (x j (t -σ -τ (t))).
div.p: Taking the upper right Dini derivative with respect to t along the solution of (12), it can follow that:
div.formula: D + V (e(t)) = lim h→0 + e(t + h) ω -e(t) ω h = lim h→0 + e(t) + h ė(t) + o(h) ω -e(t) ω h = lim h→0 + 1 h { e(t) + h(-D * e(t) + Á * f (e(t)) + B * g(e(t -τ (t))) + ( D -D * ) × x(t -σ ) + ( Á * -Á) f (x(t -σ )) + ( B * -B)g(x(t -σ -τ (t))) -K e(t)) + o(h) ω -e(t) ω } ≤ lim h→0 + I + h(-D * -K ) ω -1 h e(t) ω + Á * ω f (e(t)) ω + B * ω g(e(t -τ (t))) ω + D -D * ω x(t -σ ) ω + Á * -Á ω f (x(t -σ )) ω + B * -B ω g(x(t -σ -τ (t))) ω . (13
div.p: From Assumption (H 1 ), we have

div.p: Combining ( 13) and ( 14), from Definition 5, we obtain
div.formula: D + V (e(t)) ≤ μ ω (-D * -K ) e(t) ω + l ω 1 Á * ω e(t) ω + l ω 2 B * ω e(t -τ (t)) ω + D ω x(t -σ ) ω + A ω f (x(t -σ )) ω + B ω g(x(t -σ -τ (t))) ω ≤ (μ ω (-D * -K ) + l ω 1 Á * ω ) e(t) ω + l ω 2 B * ω sup t -τ ≤s≤t e(s) ω + D ω x(t -σ ) ω + A ω f (x(t -σ )) ω + B ω g(x(t -σ -τ (t))) ω . (15
div.p: Case 2:
div.formula: If |x i (t -σ )| > T i , |y i (t)|
div.p: > T i at time t, then master system (1) and slave system (4) reduce to the following systems, respectively:
div.formula: ẋi (t -σ ) = -di x i (t -σ ) + n j =1 àij f j (x j (t -σ )) + n i= j bij f j (x j (t -σ -τ (t))) + I i (16
div.p: and

Similar to Case 1, we can obtain
div.formula: D + V (e(t)) ≤ μ ω (-D * -K ) + l ω 1 À * ω e(t) ω + l ω 2 B * ω sup t -τ ≤s≤t e(s) ω + D ω x(t -σ ) ω + A ω f (x(t -σ )) ω + B ω g(x(t -σ -τ (t))) ω . (18

div.formula: If |x i (t -σ )| > T i , |y i (t)|

(19

div.head: IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON NEURAL NETWORKS AND LEARNING SYSTEMS
div.p: From Assumption (H 1 ), combining ( 14) and ( 19), it yields
div.formula: D + V (e(t)) ≤ μ ω (-D * -K ) e(t) ω + l ω 1 Á * ω e(t) ω + l ω 2 B * ω e(t -τ (t)) ω + D ω x(t -σ ) ω + A ω f (x(t -σ )) ω + B ω g(x(t -σ -τ (t))) ω ≤ μ ω (-D * -K ) + l ω 1 Á * ω e(t) ω + l ω 2 B * ω sup t -τ ≤s≤t e(s) ω + D ω x(t -σ ) ω + A ω f (x(t -σ )) ω + B ω g(x(t -σ -τ (t))) ω . (20
div.p: Case 4:
div.formula: If |x i (t -σ )| ≤ T i , |y i (t)| > T i
div.p: at time t, then master system (1) and slave system (4) reduce to (10) and (17). Correspondingly, the error system can be written as
Similar to Case 3, from (20), we have
div.formula: D + V (e(t)) ≤ μ ω (-D * -K ) + l ω 1 À * ω e(t) ω + l ω 2 B * ω sup t -τ ≤s≤t e(s) ω + D ω x(t -σ ) ω + A ω f (x(t -σ )) ω + B ω g(x(t -σ -τ (t))) ω . (21
div.p: Based on the above analysis [see (15) and ( 18)-( 21)], let
div.formula: α(t) = max{μ ω (-D * -K ) + l ω 1 À * ω , μ ω (-D * -K ) + l ω 1 Á * ω }, β(t) = max{l ω 2 B * ω , l ω 2 B * ω }, and γ (t) = D ω x(t -σ ) ω + A ω f (x(t -σ )) ω + B ω g(x(t -σ -τ (t))) ω . One has D + V (e(t)) ≤ γ (t) + α(t) e(t) ω + β(t) sup t -τ ≤s≤t e(s) ω .
div.p: From the conditions in Theorem 1, we have α(t) + β(t) ≤ -δ < 0, and according to Lemma 3, it can be obtained that
div.formula: e(t) ω ≤ γ * ω δ + sup -τ ≤s≤0 e(s) ω e -μ * t (22
div.p: where μ * = inf t ≥0 {μ(t) : μ(t) + α(t) + β(t)e μ(t )τ = 0}. From ( 22), we conclude that the error system converges exponentially to the set M = {e ∈ R n | e(t) ω ≤ (γ * ω /δ)}; from Definition 4, slave system (4) and master system (1) achieve lag quasi-synchronization with an error level (γ * ω /δ). This completes the proof.

Remark 2: Without constructing complex Lyapunov function, the matrix measure method [27] is a very good tool to deal with the stability and synchronization problems of neural networks; the proposed results are more general than common algebraic criterion, for which the matrix measure can be taken not only as a positive value but also as a negative value.

Remark 3: Most of the existing results deal with the synchronization problem of complex networks by adopting p-measure ( p = 1, 2, ∞); the proposed criteria are always true when ω-measure is replaced by p-measure [28].
Hence, ω-measure method [29] is equal or superior to other measure methods.

Note that Theorem 1 has given a general expression of γ * ω ; in Corollary 1, we obtain the concrete algorithm of γ * ω , and it does not require activation function satisfying f (0) = g(0) = 0, which is a common assumption in the field of neural networks.

Corollary 1: Under Assumptions (H 1 ) and (H 2 ), suppose that = {x ∈ R n | x ω ≤ h 1 ω } and parameter mismatches satisfy 0) ω . Master system (1) and slave system (4) achieve lag quasisynchronized with an error level set

div.p: Proof: From Assumption (H 1 ), we have
div.formula: f (x) ω ≤ l ω 1 x ω + f (0) ω g(x) ω ≤ l ω 2 x ω + g(0) ω . Since x ω ≤ h 1 ω , we can obtain D ω x(t -σ ) ω + A ω f (x(t -σ )) ω + B ω g(x(t -σ -τ (t))) ω ≤ D ω h 1 ω + A ω l ω 1 h 1 ω + f (0) ω + B ω l ω 2 h 1 ω + g(0) ω = h 1 ω h 2 ω + A ω f (0) ω + B ω g(0) ω .
div.p: Based on Theorem 1, we can draw γ * ω = h ω , and the conclusion of Corollary 1 holds immediately. This completes the proof.

Remark 4: When the master-slave system has parameter mismatch, it cannot reach the complete synchronization, and the error bound of lag quasi-synchronization is estimated in accordance with the parameter mismatch in Theorem 1 and Corollary 1.

Remark 5: The obtained results can be easily extended to the generalized {ξ, 1}-norm in [30] and [31], which is another useful tool to study the synchronization of masterslave system, and it can unify ω i and ω j with a constant ξ i .

Hence, e(t) converges exponentially to zero with a convergence rate of r , and this completes the proof of Theorem 2. Remark 6: It is worth emphasizing that the master-slave system with parameters match [32] will reach to complete synchronization when conditions 1)-3) in Theorem 2 hold; moreover, the proposed conditions depend on the jump point T i of memristive neural networks (1); hence, the results in this paper have less conservativeness and expand the results in the existing literatures.

Remark 7: Memristive neural networks (1) can be seen as a special switching neural networks model, whose switching rule depends on its states, when di = di , áij = àij , bij = bij , and T i is a arbitrary positive constant, and then the memristive neural networks (1) change as common recurrent neural networks.

Remark 8: In some existing papers, the activation function needs to meet f i (±T i ) = g i (±T i ) = 0, which is a strong condition, and most of the functions do not have this property. However, the activation function in this paper only needs to satisfy the Lipschitz condition, even if it does not need f i (0) = g i (0) = 0, which is suitable and more general.

div.head: IV. TWO ILLUSTRATIVE EXAMPLES
div.p: In this section, two illustrative examples will be given to check the validity of the results obtained in Theorems 1 and 2.
Example 1: Consider the following memristor-based recurrent neural networks:
where
The slave system with parameter mismatch defines as where

Take time delay τ (t) = (e t /e t + 1) and an activation function f (x) = g(x) = (sin x 1 , sin x 2 ) T . Assumption (H 1 ) holds with l ω 1 = l ω 2 = 1, suppose ω 1 = ω 2 = 1, by observing that the phase trajectory (see Fig. 4) of system (32) is contained in the set = {x ∈ R n | x ω ≤ 6}, and the parameter mismatch satisfy D ω = 0, A ω = 0.3, and B ω = 0.3. Thus, one obtains that h 1 ω = 6, h 2 ω = 0.6, and γ * ω = 3.6. Set M = {e ∈ R n | e(t) ω ≤ 0.5}, that is, the error level is less than 0.5, and then, we have δ = 7.2, and the control gain parameter is taken as k 1 = k 2 = 20; it is obvious that all the conditions in Theorem 1 hold. For making numerical simulation, take transmittal delay σ = 1, i.e., e(t) = y(t)x(t -1), and the state trajectories of master system and slave system are described in Figs. 5 and6. One can find that y(t) approximately retards x(t) by 1 s. The synchronization errors e 1 (t) and e 2 (t) are given in Figs. 7 and8, from which we can see that the error level is less than 0.5 by using suitable controller; the master-slave chaotic memristive neural networks with parameter mismatch can reach to quasi-synchronization, and it proves the proposed results in Theorem 1.
The second example is to specialize the results of Theorem 2; here master-slave mermristor system can reach to lag complete synchronization.

Example 2: Consider the following 2-D mermristor-based recurrent neural networks: where conditions in Theorem 2. In the following, we will verify the correctness by MATLAB simulation. The phase trajectory of states x 1 (t) and x 2 (t) with initial conditions x 1 (t) = -1.3 cos(t) and x 2 (t) = -1.1 sin(2t) is described in Fig. 9, taking y 1 (t) = 1.5 sin(3t) and y 2 (t) = 1.3 cos(3t), ∀t ∈ [-1, 0], when there is no control input, i.e., control gains k i = η i = 0; the error trajectories of master-slave system are shown in Figs. 10-12 representing the change in coefficients a 12 (x 1 (t)) and a 12 (y 1 (t)), which can prove that the memristive-coupled networks cannot reach to synchronization without a controller. However, the memristive master-slave system can reach to synchronization by using the above controller, and the error trajectories e 1 (t) and e 2 (t) of memristive-coupled networks are described in Fig. 15, and Figs. 13 and 14 show that slave system (34) approximately follows master system (35) with transmit delay 1 s.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, the effect of parameter mismatch on lag synchronization of the coupled memristive neural networks has been studied, by using ω-measure method and Halanay inequality. The simple criteria are derived to ensure the lag synchronization of memristive neural networks with or without parameter mismatch. The effectiveness of the proposed approach has been illustrated by numerical simulation. Memristor-based neural networks is a new and challenging topic, looking for more complex and practical memristor-based neural networks model is our further work. Since memristor-based neural networks model can be seen as a discontinuous switched system, it is necessary to employ the more advanced mathematical method to study.

div.p: This work was supported in part by the National Natural Science Foundation of China under Grant 61573096 and Grant 61272530, in part by the Natural Science Foundation of Jiangsu Province of China under Grant BK2012741, and in part by the 333 Engineering Foundation of Jiangsu Province of China under Grant BRA2015286. Ning Li received the B.S. degree in applied mathematics from Zhoukou Normal University, Henan, China, in 2010, the M.S. degree in computational mathematics from Yanshan University, Qinhuangdao, China, in 2012, and the Ph.D. degree from Southeast University, Nanjing, China, in 2015. Jinde Cao (M'07-SM'07) received the B.S. degree from Anhui Normal University, Wuhu, China, in 1989, the M.S. degree from Yunnan University, Kunming, China, in 1989, and the Ph.D. degree from Sichuan University, Chengdu, China, in 1998, all in mathematics/applied mathematics. He was with Yunnan University from 1989 to 2000, where he was a Professor from 1996 to 2000. In 2000, he joined the Department of Mathematics, Southeast University, Nanjing, China, where he is currently the Dean of the Department of Mathematics. From 2001 to 2002, he was a Post-Doctoral Research Fellow with the
